p: Phragmites australis is a cosmopolitan wetland grass with multiple lineages worldwide and is considered a model organism for studying plant invasions (Meyerson et al., 2016). Invasive to North America, the European lineage ( P. australis haplotype M; hereafter, non‐native Phragmites) is highly productive and fast growing, often forming dense stands supporting a low overall species diversity. A native lineage in North America ( Phragmites australis subsp. americanus, hereafter native Phragmites) is conversely characteristic of low nutrient, high‐diversity wetlands and is considered desirable for wildlife habitat (Price et al., 2013).
